Yes, it is possible that the regulation of gas in ammonite shells was not purely an instinctual behavior and could have involved some form of neural network. The siphuncle, which connects the chambers of the shell and controls the amount of gas in each, was a complex structure, and some researchers have suggested that there may have been a specialized tissue or organ located near the siphuncle that controlled the regulation of gas.

Studies have also shown that some modern-day cephalopods, which are closely related to ammonites, possess neural structures known as "ganglia" that control the flow of gas between chambers in their shells. While there is no direct evidence that ammonites possessed similar structures, it is possible that they had some sort of neural network that controlled the gas regulation process.

However, because ammonites are extinct, it is difficult to know for sure how their shells functioned and how they regulated the flow of gas. Without direct evidence, researchers must rely on indirect evidence, such as analysis of fossilized shells and comparisons to modern-day cephalopods, to infer how ammonites lived and behaved.
